user_request: A poem about a road not taken and the difference it made.

revision_history.draft:
# Tire Smoke and Wet Glass

The radio plays something I half-remember—
some woman saying *almost* like it was a flavor,
almost-banana, almost-blackberry,
and my left hand holds the wheel so hard
the steering wheel is a thing I'm hugging
through a dark tunnel.

Rain on glass. That sound again,
that particular animal sound,
wet leather stripping from wet asphalt,
every mile swallowed under that strip
of white light ahead, then black.
I press harder when something's
already pressed. My body believes
in the principle of not giving an inch.

On the dashboard, the speedo ticks
its mad rabbit away—sixty, sixty-one,
and behind us, what was ours, is not
a choice but a texture, the road
dissolving under fog like hair
pulling back from a scalp that's cooling.
Weeds along the shoulder bend
the wrong direction. The mirage
of exit ramps and painted lines
smiles at us with cracked teeth,
all of it sliding off the lens
at sixty miles per second.

There was no choosing, really—just
the engine's rhythmic refusal
to think about where it's going,
and me not correcting for it.
This is not a moment to gather meaning from.
Meaning will find me later, tucked
in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking.

What stays here on the seats,
on the leather we've softened
into almost-synonymous,
is the smell of rain on engine oil—
that particular note of almost-clean,
and under it, something the car
has always had and will carry home:
the knowledge that every stop
was just a temporary decision
to stop knowing.

The turn signal clicks.
I let it. There's nothing on the right.
Fog all the way to the shoulders,
and I can see my own breath
doing its small work in the glass.
The tire smoke left behind
is not a choice—just heat and rubber
going back to what they were before
they became interesting.

I press harder again. The car
does not remember my name.
The wet pavement says only
*here we part,* which is
less than a quote and more
the sound a river makes
when it finally understands
it was never yours to hold.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has genuine structural ambition — the engine-compartment conceit is doing real work, and the central idea (loss of control before anyone notices) lands with force. The turn signal near the end ("I can see my own breath / doing its small work in the glass") is a sharp moment: it earns its abstraction by grounding it in breath fogging a window. That's where trust between image and meaning happens.

The line "the steering wheel is a thing I'm hugging" has physical specificity — it resists sentimentalizing the scene, which is what most road poems do at this point.

The closing four lines ("*here we part,* which is / less than a quote and more / the sound a river makes / when it finally understands / it was never yours to hold") arrive after enough earned material that they don't quite collapse into aphorism. The river line at least tries something different from what's expected.

The poem is strongest in its first 25 lines — roughly the engine-compartment and early fog sections. That's where the poet has stayed inside the car, stayed inside the situation, and stayed close to actual sensory data.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / emotional over-explanation (lines 43–50):**
"Meaning will find me later, tucked
in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking."
This paragraph *tells* what the poem has already shown. The hands hugging the steering wheel (line 4) and the body's refusal to give an inch (line 12) are doing the work here. The explanation weakens it by naming "meaning" as a concept rather than letting the image hold weight.

**Direction:** Cut or compress this passage entirely. Let the hands be remembered only through their physicality — not through self-commentary about remembering.

---

**Cliché / dead language:**
- "a flavor, almost-banana, almost-blackberry" — three near-misses in a row for the same abstraction (taste). This is the poem reaching for something it hasn't committed to yet.
- "mad rabbit away" — personification that's decorative rather than earned
- "fog all the way to the shoulders" — vague spatial language. What does fog do at the shoulder? Say that.
- "the knowledge that every stop / was just a temporary decision / to stop knowing." — this is the poem explaining its own theme back to itself, which kills tension.

**Direction:** Each of these moments needs to be cut or replaced with something observed, not generalized. What does fog actually do at the edge of pavement? What's the texture of wet glass under wiper blades when it's cold — say that in a line and stop.

---

**Abstraction

revision_history.draft:
# Tire Smoke and Wet Glass

The radio plays a station I half-remember—
some guitar thread hummed so slightly
it could be almost anything, the kind of note
you find in silence and mistake for it.

My left hand holds the wheel like a thing
I'm hugging through a dark tunnel.
Rain on glass. That particular animal sound,
wet leather stripping from wet asphalt—
every mile swallowed under that strip
of white light ahead, then black.

I press harder when something's already pressed.
My body believes in the principle of not giving an inch.

On the dashboard, the speedo ticks its mad rabbit away:
sixty, sixty-one. And behind us,
what was ours has thinned to texture—
the road dissolving under fog like hair pulling back from a scalp that's cooling.
Weeds along the shoulder bend the wrong direction.
The mirage of exit ramps and painted lines
smiles at us with cracked teeth:
all of it sliding off the lens at sixty miles per second.

There was no choosing, really—just
the engine's rhythmic refusal
to think about where it's going,
and me not correcting for it.
This is not a moment to gather meaning from.
Meaning will find me later, tucked
in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking.

What stays here on the seats—
on the leather we've softened
into almost-synonymous—is

the smell of rain on engine oil: that particular note
of almost-clean, and under it, something the car
has always had and will carry home:
the knowledge that every stop was just a temporary decision
to stop knowing.

The turn signal clicks. I let it.
There's nothing on the right—fog all the way to the shoulders,
and my own breath doing its small work in the glass.

Under the wipers, rain and wiper fluid cold together
on windscreen, that thin sheet of water
you can read through even when you're moving fast:
the fog doesn't hold still. It peels back from headlights
like cracked fingernail polish. The car throws
each weed so fully sideways it looks stunned,
every leaf a small mouth opening then closing.

I don't correct for anything.
The tire smoke left behind is not a choice—just heat and rubber
going back to what they were before
they became interesting.

The fog thins where the headlights push through it,
and I can see one turn signal ahead, steady,
its redness clean as something handed to you.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The engine-compartment conceit is the strongest structural choice here, and the poem earns real specificity in its first two-thirds:

- **Line 3: "My left hand holds the wheel so hard / the steering wheel is a thing I'm hugging"** — physical, visceral, avoids the expected "hugging through darkness." The steering wheel as something held.
- **Lines 15–20:** "Weeds along the shoulder bend / the wrong direction. The mirage / of exit ramps and painted lines / smiles at us with cracked teeth" — this is where the poem's attention lands on actual road imagery, not sentiment. "Smiles at us with cracked teeth" earns its grotesquerie.
- **Lines 23–25:** "the fog doesn't hold still. It peels back from headlights / like cracked fingernail polish" — the fog as something that *peels* is precise and visual, not decorative.
- **The closing turn signal image (lines 47–50):** "I can see my own breath / doing its small work in the glass." This earns its abstraction ("here we part") because it arrives after enough grounded sensory material. The river line also tries something different.

These are moments where the poem trusts itself to show rather than tell, and trust is what this draft needs everywhere else.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / emotional over-explanation (lines 37–40):**
"Meaning will find me later, tucked
in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking."
This is the poem explaining its own theme back to itself. It kills tension and replaces image with abstraction.

**Direction:** Cut entirely or replace with something that stays in the physical scene — what are the hands actually doing, where are they resting? The steering wheel already did this work.

---

**Abstraction / dead language (throughout):**
- "some guitar thread hummed so slightly / it could be almost anything" — three near-misses for a single abstraction. Cut or commit.
- "That particular animal sound, / wet leather stripping from wet asphalt" — "wet leather" is vague; what kind of noise? What surface?
- "the speedo ticks its mad rabbit away: sixty, sixty-one" — personification that's decorative rather than earned
- "on the dashboard, the speedo ticks its mad rabbit away" — the poem narrates its own metaphor instead of letting it breathe
- "all of it sliding off the lens at sixty miles per second" — this is the poet explaining what the road does. The image before and after ("mirage of exit ramps") already shows it.
- "the knowledge that every stop was just a temporary decision / to

revision_history.draft:
# Tire Smoke and Wet Glass

The radio drifts through a station I half-remember—
some guitar thread, the kind of note you find
in fog and mistake for it.

My left hand hovers like a thing
I'm hugging while driving. Rain on glass.
That particular animal sound,
tire silk stripping from wet asphalt—

every mile swallowed under that strip
of white light ahead then black.

I don't ease off when the steering is already pulled hard.
My body believes in staying pressed to the wheel's idea
of not giving an inch.

On the dashboard, the speedo ticks its rabbit away:
sixty. Sixty-one. The fog outside has thinned to texture—
road dissolving under it like hair pulling back from a scalp that's cooling.
Weeds along the shoulder bend the wrong direction.
Exit ramps and painted lines smile with cracked teeth,
all of them sliding off the lens at sixty miles per second.

There was no choosing, really—just
the engine's rhythmic refusal
to think about where it's going,
and me not correcting for that.

On the seats: rain on engine oil—that particular note
of almost-clean and under it something the car
has always carried home:
every stop a temporary decision to stop knowing.

The turn signal clicks. I let it.
Nothing on the right—fog all the way to the shoulders,
and my own breath fogging the glass in small, careful circles.

Wipers scrape rain and wiper fluid cold together
on windscreen, that thin sheet of water you can read through
even when moving fast: headlights pushing back the fog
like cracked fingernail polish peeling from a nail.
Each weed bent so fully sideways it looks stunned,
every leaf opening then closing like small mouths.

I don't correct. The tire smoke left behind is not a choice—just heat and rubber
going back to what they were before
they became interesting.

The fog thins where headlights push through it,
and I can see one steady turn signal ahead,
its redness clean as something handed to you.

in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking."
This is the poem explaining its own theme back to itself. It kills tension and replaces image with abstraction.

**Abstraction / dead language (throughout):**

revision_history.draft:
# Tire Smoke and Wet Glass

A station's one guitar string
rides the frequency I half-remember losing—
not a note, but the accident of it,
the way rain smooths glass into something you mistake for silence.

My left hand opens around the wheel like a fist
letting go of its last grip on anything clean. Rain on windscreen.
A fox yaps in the shoulder weeds, three hundred feet from us,
but that sound arrives already broken, the way language is
when it crosses fields at night and returns changed.

I don't ease off when the steering's pulled past hard.
My knuckles go white then loose their grip like a held breath—
that particular soft letting-go you can feel in the tendons
just below the wrist. The dashboard tick:
speedo's rabbit hopping its small legs toward sixty,
then sixty-one, and outside: fog drawn back to texture,
road dissolving under it like hair pulling from a scalp that's cooled.

On the right, the shoulder's dark with wet grass.
A weed bends so fully sideways I can see
the soil inside it, the bright gut of it
closing its small mouth around the wind—each leaf
doing this individually, fiercely. My wipers scrape rain and fluid
across one thin sheet of window where headlights push through the fog
like cracked fingernail polish peeling from a nail.

I don't correct. The tire smoke left behind is not a choice—it's heat,
rubber returning to what it was before it became interesting.
That black smear tells me nothing about direction, but I watch it anyway.

The turn signal clicks its one silver tooth
into the plastic socket. Fog all the way to the shoulders now—
my own breath fogging the left side window in small, careful circles,
each one erased by the wiper before it sets.
Wipers scrape and windscreen holds what's left: that thin sheet of water
you can read through even when moving fast.

The headlights push back the fog like a coat
 sliding off a sleeping body. Each steady turn signal ahead
a redness clean as something handed to you, not chosen—
just held at the wrist, weight in the hand,
the way you hold anything that isn't leaving.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The engine-compartment conceit is genuinely compelling, and the poem lands with real force in its first two-thirds.

**Line 3: "My left hand hovers like a thing / I'm hugging while driving."** — This is the strongest opening line because it earns physical specificity before any abstraction arrives. The steering wheel as something held.

**Lines 15–20:** "Weeds along the shoulder bend / the wrong direction. The mirage / of exit ramps and painted lines / smiles at us with cracked teeth" — this is where attention lands on actual road imagery, not sentiment. "Smiles at us with cracked teeth" earns its grotesquerie.

**Lines 23–25:** "The fog thins where headlights push through it,
like cracked fingernail polish peeling from a nail." — The fog as something that *peels* is precise and visual, not decorative. This line does what the whole poem should do: show rather than tell.

**Lines 47–50:** "I can see my own breath / doing its small work in the glass." — The river line tries something different (a closing metaphor of separation) that actually works because it arrives after enough grounded sensory material. The final image earns its abstraction ("here we part") by staying physical.

**"Tire smoke left behind is not a choice—it's heat,"** — the poem's central conceit gets stated with real economy in line 38, and the rest of that sentence (cut from previous draft) completes it: "rubber returning to what it was before it became interesting." That's precise.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / emotional over-explanation (lines 37–40):**
"Meaning will find me later, tucked
in bed, the car a story I can't recall,
my hands still posed like someone
holding positions they won't remember taking."
This is the poem explaining its own theme back to itself. It kills tension and replaces image with abstraction.

**Direction:** Cut entirely or replace with something that stays in the physical scene — what are the hands actually doing, where are they resting? The steering wheel already did this work.

---

**Abstraction / dead language:**

- **"some guitar thread, the kind of note you find / in fog and mistake for it."** — Three near-misses for a single abstraction. Cut or commit.
- **"That particular animal sound,
wet leather stripping from wet asphalt—"
"leather" is vague; what surface? What texture?
- **"the mad rabbit away: sixty, sixty-one"** — personification that's decorative rather than earned
- **"all of it sliding off the lens at sixty miles per second"** — this is the poet explaining what the road does. The image

final_poem:
A station's one guitar string
rides the frequency I half-remember losing—
not a note, but the accident of it,
the way rain smooths glass into something you mistake for silence.

My left hand opens around the wheel like a fist
letting go of its last grip on anything clean. Rain on windscreen.
A fox yaps in the shoulder weeds, three hundred feet from us,
but that sound arrives already broken, the way language is
when it crosses fields at night and returns changed.

I don't ease off when the steering's pulled past hard.
My knuckles go white then loose their grip like a held breath—
that particular soft letting-go you can feel in the tendons
just below the wrist. The dashboard tick:
speedo's rabbit hopping its small legs toward sixty,
then sixty-one, and outside: fog drawn back to texture,
road dissolving under it like hair pulling from a scalp that's cooled.

On the right, the shoulder's dark with wet grass.
A weed bends so fully sideways I can see
the soil inside it, the bright gut of it
closing its small mouth around the wind—each leaf
doing this individually, fiercely. My wipers scrape rain and fluid
across one thin sheet of window where headlights push through the fog
like cracked fingernail polish peeling from a nail.

I don't correct. The tire smoke left behind is not a choice—it's heat,
rubber returning to what it was before it became interesting.
That black smear tells me nothing about direction, but I watch it anyway.

The turn signal clicks its one silver tooth
into the plastic socket. Fog all the way now—
my own breath fogging the left side window in small, careful circles,
each one erased by the wiper before it sets.
Wipers scrape and windscreen holds what's left: that thin sheet of water
you can read through even when moving fast.

Headlights push back the fog like a coat
sliding off a sleeping body. Each steady turn signal ahead
a redness clean as something handed to you, not chosen—
just held at the wrist, weight in the hand,
the way you hold anything that isn't leaving.
The wiper blade finds its groove again and I let it pull
fog from glass like cracked polish lifting from a nail.
